body:
I'd also find this feature quite appealing. While I understand that this adds an additional hop to data transfer and some additional complexity to the tracking server, often it may not be that easy or even viable to ensure that every client has access to the underlying artefacts store, e.g., S3.

Do you have any plans in this regard?

I'm adding my vote to this issue, as we're facing the same problem.
In our case, we have the server running on a standalone server, and clients coming from pc notebooks (e.g. Jupyter) and code or from Databricks notebooks.
The don't all share the same access to S3.

I request tracking server proxy uploads to S3, as well. Setting up MLflow server as a multi-tenant solution is difficult when credentials have to be shared between autonomous teams in our organization, each using the own AWS accounts. It seems awkward that clients must possess the same credentials as the server, and it goes against the flexibility provided by the MLflow client SDK.

Mounting S3 as a file system on the mlflow server with `s3fs`, and then setting the `--default-artifact-root` option to that filesystem locally could solve the problem, but in a very roundabout way.

I also would like this feature, and +1-ed this issue above. Had a quick exchange on Slack with @acroz, who suggested I comment here.

My suggestion is to support two options.

**Option 1: direct client-to-repo artifact uploads (already supported)**
Pro: does not impose requirement for extra server compute resources
Con: requires additional configuration that at best must be managed for each client, at worst is not practical (as others have noted above)

**Option 2: proxied client-to-server-to-repo artifact uploads**
Pro: simpler client configuration
Con: requires additional server-side compute resources

I would suggest Option 2 as the default, because it is an easier getting-started experience. Which as a breaking change, should be done before 1.0.

Note that this feature might impact the [current proposal](https://gist.github.com/acroz/48a7b9455f1a054f6b14acf676d6df46) for changes to the artifact repo API. I have not studied the proposal and code base closely enough to be sure.

Would love to hear from the maintainers on this topic.
@smurching @aarondav @mparkhe

I also support this change, it would simplify a lot storing into the tracking server.

Right now, if I want to store the artifacts in the local storage of the tracking server, I need to set up a sftp server (or ftp) and handle all the key management correctly.
Supporting both seems like a good way. Default should IMO be client to server to repo.

We've just started using MLflow, and the existing behaviour was slightly _[astonishing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principle_of_least_astonishment)_. Maybe I am missing the use-case for why it is the way it is, but it seems to make configuration on the server, and client more brittle

That said, I can understand if the client uploads directly to say S3. It saves unnecessary data transfer. And it is relatively achievable without the need of credentials on the client-side using presigned URLs (https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/PresignedUrlUploadObject.html). So this may be a potential option too for some cloud-based artifact storage.

I am not aware of any resolution to this issue.
